author: By Kevin Roose
title: Can Clubhouse Move Fast Without Breaking Things?
description: The 11-month-old audio social network is compelling. It also has some very grown-up problems.
content: A few nights ago, after my weekly trip to the grocery store, I sat in my car glued to Clubhouse, the invitation-only social audio app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What Students Are Saying About Vaccine Trials, Sports Without Spectators and a Chaotic Year
description: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
content: Welcome to another roundup of student comments on our writing prompts. This week we asked teenagers if they would volunteer for a Covid-19 vaccine trial, if they are missing live sports and how they have dealt with a chaotic year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard H. Pildes
title: How to Keep Extremists Out of Power
description: Every political reform proposal must be judged by its ability to fuel or weaken extremist candidates.
content: American democracy faces alarming risks from extremist forces that have rapidly gained ground in our politics. The most urgent focus of political reform must be to marginalize, to the extent possible, these destabilizing forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Rajie Cook, Who Helped Make Sense of Public Spaces, Dies at 90
description: He and Don Shanosky developed the pictogram symbols widely used to identify airports, restrooms and more. He was also an artist known for his sculptural assemblages.
content: Rajie Cook often joked that museumgoers were more likely to encounter his artwork in their travels than a portrait by Matisse or a landscape by van Gogh. They saw it whenever they took an elevator to an upper gallery or stopped in the restroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni, Jim Tankersley and Emily Cochrane
title: The White House continues to fight for Tanden’s confirmation, a battle it didn’t expect to wage.
description: Neera Tanden had been seen as a strong pick to serve as budget director, but her past tweets became a sticking point with Republicans.
content: On Wednesday night, Ron Klain, the White House chief of staff, went on television to proclaim that the Biden administration was still “fighting our guts out” to get Neera Tanden confirmed as the head of the Office of Management and Budget.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Loretta Whitfield, Creator of a Doll With a Difference, Dies at 79
description: In the 1980s, amid the craze for Cabbage Patch Kids, she and her husband came up with an alternative: Baby Whitney, a doll with realistic Black features.
content: In the early 1980s, Melvin Whitfield was working for a health nonprofit in West Africa when he came to a realization: Few of the children he encountered had dolls, and the dolls he did see were modeled after white European faces and bodies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Grode
title: The Birth of ‘Rent,’ Its Creator’s Death and the 25 Years Since
description: With a virtual performance marking the Broadway musical’s anniversary, original cast and creative team members talk about losing Jonathan Larson and carrying on his legacy.
content: What’s 525,600 times 25?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: tangible
description: This word has appeared in 370 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Amber Ruffin gets a late-night slot on broadcast. And if you still miss the British “Office,” try “Stath Lets Flats.”
content: Every Monday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: At a Senate hearing and on the House floor, emotional debates erupt over transgender rights.
description: President Biden’s nominee to be assistant secretary of health, who is transgender, and a House member whose daughter is transgender, drew separate attacks from Republican lawmakers.
content: A culture war over transgender rights erupted on Capitol Hill on Thursday, as a Republican senator attacked President Biden’s nominee to a top health post, and two members of the House — one the mother of a transgender daughter — sparred over legislation that would extend civil rights protections to L.G.B.T.Q. people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Giaimo
title: The Outsized Influence of Teen T. Rex and Other Young Dinosaurs
description: A deep dive into dinosaur data suggests that teenage T. rexes and other juvenile carnivores shaped their ecosystems.
content: Adolescence is a time of great change for most of us. But it was particularly volatile for young T. rexes. Before they became fearsome, bone-crushing adults, they had to pass through a number of stages — two-foot hatchling, gangly preteen, bulky young adult. At each phase, they hunted different prey and filled different niches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘The United States vs. Billie Holiday’ Review: Singing for Her Life
description: Lee Daniels’s hectic biopic portrays the singer as a victim of abuse, addiction and government persecution.
content: Every great musician is one of a kind, but the biographies of great musicians — or more precisely their biopics — end up looking pretty much alike. Childhood trauma is followed by success and its consequences, usually including addiction and love trouble. A chronicle of artistic triumph doubles as a cautionary tale, with ruin and redemption wrapped around each other like twin strands of narrative DNA. If all else fails, the soundtrack music offers occasional reminders of why we should care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Want to Be Mayor of New York? Better Know Your Wings and Dumplings
description: Food can be a unifying or divisive factor in New York City politics, with people taking sides on pizza slices, deli choices and utensil selection.
content: Among all the things that help shape a New York City mayor’s image, it’s not always the most consequential topics that tend to stick — especially on matters that concern food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Parker
title: Romance Blossoms for Seniors During Quarantine
description: For some in assisted living residences, the lockdown has made finding a romantic companion as simple as walking down the hall.
content: When 91-year-old Sam Gallo and 86-year-old Millie Hathorn got engaged in March 2020, Mr. Gallo, who is deaf from his time as crew chief on jet planes during the Korean War, wrote a letter to his three children. “Only at death is love done,” he wrote. While they both had been married before, he wrote, “love was not done … with us.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Airbnb posts a $3.9 billion loss in its first report as public company.
description: Airbnb, which has faced sky-high expectations since its blockbuster initial public offering in December, posted declining revenue and a whopping $3.9 billion loss on Thursday in its first earnings report as a publicly traded company.
content: Airbnb, which has faced sky-high expectations since its blockbuster initial public offering in December, posted declining revenue and a whopping $3.9 billion loss on Thursday in its first earnings report as a publicly traded company.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Mental Health and Homeless Crises Collided in Subway Attacks
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, February 25, 2021.
content: “She didn’t have to be sleeping on the trains and die the way she did.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: We Want to Hear From Teen Parents
description: The Times would love to hear from you about your experience parenting as a teenager during the pandemic.
content: The Times is looking for stories of teen parents juggling caring for their own children during the pandemic while also dealing with the unique challenges of remote schooling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Cherry’ Review: A Very Different Tangled Web for Tom Holland
description: Joe and Anthony Russo, the M.C.U. filmmaking brothers, stretch out into the real world of war, crime and addiction in a gritty drama based on a best-selling novel.
content: A couple of years back, when Martin Scorsese dared to say he didn’t care for superhero movies — “that’s not cinema,” he said — two successful directors in that field, the brothers Joe and Anthony Russo, took a swipe at the older filmmaker. “At the end of the day, what do we know?” Joe said in an interview. “We’re just two guys from Cleveland, Ohio, and ‘cinema’ is a New York word.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Criminal Justice Is a State Issue
description: State power is the path to racial equality and liberation.
content: This week, Illinois became the first state to eliminate its cash bail system, and Virginia became the first Southern state to abolish the death penalty. These developments illustrate that many of the most impactful criminal justice reforms can and must be enacted by states, not by the federal government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: The Supreme Court Is Not Finished With Elections
description: The justices are about to consider whether the Voting Rights Act applies to policies that restrict the vote.
content: When the Supreme Court on Monday rejected Pennsylvania Republicans’ after-the-fact effort to invalidate late-arriving mailed ballots, it was tempting to suppose that the country’s courthouse doors had finally closed on this most litigated of presidential elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Teens and Parents: Are You Grappling With Mental Health Issues?
description: The New York Times would like to hear from parents and adolescents who are dealing with mental health challenges.
content: The adolescent experience is changing. Over the last decade, anxiety and depression — along with self-harm and suicidal thoughts — have been on the rise among young people. We’d like to hear from parents and teenagers about their experiences dealing with mental health challenges, especially before the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Yoonsoo Kim
title: ‘The Vigil’ Review: What Could Go Wrong Watching Over the Dead?
description: Money pulls in a night watcher, but a malicious spirit gets into his head in this feature debut from Keith Thomas.
content: It is Jewish tradition to have someone watch over the dead until they are buried. That person is called a shomer. Yakov (Dave Davis), a young Jewish man who has left behind a strictly Jewish-observant life, is pulled into last-minute night-watch shomer duty. He’s reluctant but could desperately use the $400 that he is promised. What could go wrong with just a few hours spent next to a dead body, anyway?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Un Film Dramatique’ Review: Students Record the Paris Suburbs
description: This documentary gives middle school children a chance to show their experiences.
content: In the documentary “Un Film Dramatique,” the artist Éric Baudelaire fulfills a commission to make a dedicated artwork for Dora Maar, a newly constructed middle school in the Saint-Denis suburb of Paris. For the project, Baudelaire filmed 21 students across four years, and he encouraged them to take up the camera themselves. The finished film demonstrates the liveliness and generosity that can come from civic-minded art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Canadians Try to Solve the Enigma of Hard Butter
description: Pandemic inspired baking has helped focus national attention on a burning question: Why does Canadian butter seem so firm?
content: MONTREAL — As Canadians nurse their pandemic blues by baking bread and pies with zeal, a mystery has engulfed the nation: Why is the country’s butter so hard and difficult to spread?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Crisis’ Review: Finding a Fix
description: Nicholas Jarecki’s new crime drama, which examines the opioid epidemic from different angles, is well-paced but often strains credulity.
content: Applying the panoramic approach of Steven Soderbergh’s “Traffic” to the subject matter of, well, “Traffic,” “Crisis” examines the intractability of the opioid epidemic through a three-pronged narrative. The writer-director, Nicholas Jarecki, who made the engrossing, “Bonfire of the Vanities”-ish thriller “Arbitrage” (2012), awkwardly pretzels a checklist of social problems into the form of a drama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: ‘WandaVision’ Lives Inside TV. Just Like We Do.
description: After a year of pandemic life, the superhero show’s inventive premise — television as both escape and prison — is all too relatable.
content: Even allowing for the pop culture invincibility of anything Marvel, Disney+’s “WandaVision” is an odd sort of superhero show to become a phenomenon. Why, of all the comic-book premises, would America in 2021 be captivated by a story about someone escaping inside classic TV as a refuge from trauma?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Jennifer Granholm is confirmed as energy secretary.
description: Ms. Granholm will oversee an agency that plays a leading role in researching and developing new energy technologies.
content: The Senate confirmed Jennifer M. Granholm to be energy secretary on Thursday, positioning the former governor of Michigan to play a key role in President Biden’s plans to confront climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Leibovich
title: Neera Tanden: First Cabinet-Level Casualty of the Twitter Age?
description: Republicans have criticized her tweets, but Democrats say former President Donald J. Trump’s were much worse as they assail what they call a double standard.
content: WASHINGTON — Neera Tanden, you might have heard, has a Twitter problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellie Shechet
title: Manatees May Carry Half a Million Microscopic Hitchhikers
description: Unexpected species of nematodes, some of them new to science, were found living on the skin of the marine mammals.
content: Invisible worms are everywhere. Nematodes are roundworms that are mostly microscopic (although some are upsettingly large) that have adapted to a spectacular range of homes, from Antarctic soil to the inside of your gut. They are present in so many microenvironments that Nathan Cobb, a nematologist in the early 20th century, once predicted that “if all the matter in the universe except the nematodes were swept away, our world would still be dimly recognizable.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Ad Council vaccine campaign begins rolling out nationwide.
description: A broad promotional effort to combat Covid-19 vaccine skepticism began rolling out on Thursday, backed by the nonprofit advertising group Ad Council and a coalition of experts known as the Covid Collaborative.
content: A broad promotional effort to combat Covid-19 vaccine skepticism began rolling out on Thursday, backed by the nonprofit advertising group Ad Council and a coalition of experts known as the Covid Collaborative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘The Father’ Review: A Capricious Mind
description: Anthony Hopkins gives a scalding performance as a man stricken by dementia in this clever drama.
content: At once stupendously effective and profoundly upsetting, “The Father” might be the first movie about dementia to give me actual chills. On its face a simple, uncomfortably familiar story about the heartbreaking mental decline of a beloved parent, this first feature from the French novelist and playwright Florian Zeller plays with perspective so cleverly that maintaining any kind of emotional distance is impossible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Nursing Home Deaths Plummet
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: There are two new pieces of encouraging news about the pandemic — and two worrisome developments. Let’s take them one at a time, starting with the positive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitra Taj, Anatoly Kurmanaev, Manuela Andreoni and Daniel Politi
title: Public dismay turns to anger as South American officials jump the line for vaccines.
description: The hope brought by the arrival of the first vaccines in South America is hardening into anger as inoculation campaigns have spiraled into scandal, cronyism and corruption, rocking national governments and sapping trust in the political establishment.
content: The hope brought by the arrival of the first vaccines in South America is hardening into anger as inoculation campaigns have spiraled into scandal, cronyism and corruption, rocking national governments and sapping trust in the political establishment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘My Darling Supermarket’ Review: Cosmic Tales From the Checkout Lane
description: The director Tali Yankelevich applies an experimental flair to her documentary about supermarket workers in Brazil.
content: Somewhere in São Paulo, Brazil, there’s a supermarket that looks awfully familiar. It has white fluorescent lights and endless shopping lanes. Every day, there’s bread to bake and meat to grind. It’s the kind of store you might find anywhere in the world. Yet, by the end of the slight but intriguingly strange documentary “My Darling Supermarket,” it might as well be on Mars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Julien Baker Explores the Art of Doubt on ‘Little Oblivions’
description: The Tennessee singer and songwriter’s third album upends assumptions and embraces new sonic elements.
content: In 2015, when the young Tennessee singer and songwriter Julien Baker released her quietly lacerating debut album, “Sprained Ankle,” she arrived with an origin story that flashed the false promise of condensing her in just three loaded words: Christian, queer, sober.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Like Beige and Lilac
description: We bet you’ll enjoy Dylan Schiff’s debut.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I hope it comes as no surprise that I, the writer of a column about crossword puzzles, have many niche interests. With that in mind, this puzzle scratched a number of itches for me: Obscure car models and makers, quirks of citations, cartographic lingo and card games are all present in this grid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman
title: How the Pandemic Nearly Tore Israel Apart
description: Lockdowns brought tensions between secular and ultra-Orthodox communities to the boiling point. The political consequences could be felt for years to come.
content: On Jan 31, one month after Israel declared its third lockdown of the pandemic, Rabbi Meshulam Dovid Soloveitchik succumbed to the coronavirus at 99. Soloveitchik was the head of the Brisk Yeshiva in Jerusalem, an elite school for ultra-Orthodox Jews, and as news of his death spread, thousands of followers prepared to mourn him. A grand funeral was required, and according to tradition, it would need to take place as soon as possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: More Adult Americans Are Identifying as L.G.B.T., Gallup Poll Finds
description: A survey found that 5.6 percent of adults described themselves as L.G.B.T. in 2020, up from 4.5 percent in 2017.
content: A Gallup survey released Wednesday has found that more adult Americans are identifying as L.G.B.T., a shift that pollsters see as driven, at least in part, by people in younger generations who are more likely to consider themselves to be something other than heterosexual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘What Students Are Saying About Race and Racism in America’
description: In this lesson, students will read what 36 teenagers think about these important, complicated, personal and often painful topics and then reflect on what they think as well.
content: Featured Article: “What Students Are Saying About Race and Racism in America” by Nicole Daniels (also available as a PDF)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: Pfizer will test a booster shot and develop an adapted vaccine to address variant concerns.
description: Pfizer and BioNTech believe their existing vaccine still offers good protection against circulating variants, and see the plan as a way of learning how to deal with a more threatening mutation.
content: As concerns grow that new coronavirus variants could blunt the protective effects of vaccines, Pfizer and BioNTech said on Thursday that they planned to test a third booster shot as well as update their original vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: MicroStrategy adds another billion dollars of Bitcoin to its balance sheet.
description: Michael Saylor, the chief executive of the business intelligence software firm MicroStrategy, believes deeply in Bitcoin and has urged other companies to shift their corporate cash into the cryptocurrency. That’s what MicroStrategy has been doing, in a bigger way than the others that have put Bitcoin on their balance sheets, the DealBook newsletter reports.

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Tiger Woods and Another Terrible Turn of Fate
description: It is easy to cling to memories of Tiger Woods at his peaks, but his vulnerability tells as much, if not more, about his powerful hold on sport and culture.
content: The sight of his demolished S.U.V., sitting forlornly on a grassy Southern California hillside, belied the image of Tiger Woods as an invincible force marching across the golf course to certain, thrilling triumph.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Nicole Brown
title: How Moschino’s Movie Got Made
description: Inspired by a scene from the 1939 film, “The Women,” Jeremy Scott gets creative with Dita Von Teese, Maye Musk and a cast of supermodels for his Fall 2021 show.
content: In an echoing soundstage off an uneven access road on the east side of Los Angeles in early February, men and women in personal protective equipment and lots of Moschino outfits were darting around monitors and director’s chairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: DoorDash losses surge in first earnings report since going public.
description: The delivery service warned that its boost from the pandemic might fade as the vaccine rollout continued.
content: In its first earnings report as a public company, DoorDash showed how it has benefited from the pandemic even as it hinted that difficulties might lie ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood, Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: Pakistan and India Renew Pledge on Cease-Fire at Troubled Border
description: The agreement between the nuclear-armed neighbors to keep a lid on tensions along the so-called Line of Control was welcomed in the region.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan and India on Thursday reaffirmed their commitment to a cease-fire along the troubled border between the two countries after a year of bloody skirmishes, a move welcomed in both countries for lowering tensions between the nuclear-armed neighbors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Laughs Off Mike Pence’s Renewed Loyalty to Trump
description: “I don’t know where the line is between forgiving and being a doormat, but Mike Pence crossed it a long time ago,” Trevor Noah said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: California has now lost more people to Covid-19 than any other state in the U.S.
description: A bleak reminder that the recent progress the state has made against the pandemic may be fragile.
content: “It’s really hard to put all of it into words.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By MJ Franklin
title: 13 Y.A. Books to Add to Your Reading List This Spring
description: A retelling of “The Great Gatsby,” a healer fighting for her freedom and more: Here are 13 upcoming Y.A. titles you won’t want to miss this spring.
content: ‘Yolk,’ by Mary H.K. Choi (Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers, March 2)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: House Passes Sweeping Gay and Transgender Equality Legislation
description: The bill, first passed by the Democratic-led House in 2019, faces a steep climb in the Senate. It was approved as Democrats and Republicans sparred more broadly over transgender rights.
content: WASHINGTON — A divided House on Thursday narrowly passed a bill that would extend civil rights protections to prohibit discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity, but the measure faced an uphill battle to enactment, with Republicans almost uniformly opposed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Helping People Find Covid-19 Vaccines Is Aim of C.D.C.-Backed Site
description: VaccineFinder.org is an ambitious but limited attempt to simplify Americans’ search for vaccines.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, hoping to make it easier for Americans to find Covid-19 vaccines, is backing the test of a centralized online portal where the public can search for nearby vaccination locations with doses on hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller and Juliet Macur
title: Human Trafficking Charges and Coach’s Death Reopen Gymnastics’ Deep Wounds
description: John Geddert died by suicide shortly after he was charged with human trafficking and criminal sexual conduct, Michigan prosecutors said.
content: The sexual abuse crisis that has shaken American gymnastics deepened on Thursday when a coach of the 2012 women’s Olympic team was charged with human trafficking and sexually assaulting a teenage girl, before killing himself a short time later.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: A new Parisian bakery, hand-embroidered pillows — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heidi Borst
title: Navigating My Son’s A.D.H.D. Made Me Realize I Had It, Too
description: Experts say some symptoms, especially in women, are mistaken for other conditions such as mood disorders or depression.
content: I heard my 7-year-old son’s cries of frustration loud and clear despite the closed door between us. Seconds earlier, I’d left him stationed at a desk in my bedroom, hoping he’d complete at least a portion of his virtual school assignments without me at his side while I left to wash the dishes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Biden’s Pick for Trade Representative Promises Break With Past Policy
description: Katherine Tai, the nominee to be America’s chief trade negotiator, declined to give policy specifics on tariffs and trade agreements, but laid out a broad vision of a more equitable trade policy.
content: WASHINGTON — Katherine Tai, President Biden’s pick for United States trade representative, promised lawmakers during her confirmation hearing on Thursday that she would work with Congress to help reinvigorate the economy and aggressively enforce American trade rules against China, Mexico and other trading partners.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 12 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: It can be misleading to talk about “the church” — the Black church, the evangelical church, whatever — as a monolithic institution, since it blurs the real differences that exist among denominations or congregations, even among the different members of any given parish. The church is an institution in the same way as “the press” or “the judiciary,” which is to say: It is one, but it’s messy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: TV Taught Me About AIDS. ‘It’s a Sin’ Reminded Me How Far We’ve Come.
description: The new HBO Max series, set amid the first decade of the AIDS crisis in London, prompts a writer’s memories and regrets to come flooding back.
content: I met Josh at the Roxy, where we made out to “Gypsy Woman.” We went back to my N.Y.U. dorm room. We used condoms. I don’t know what happened to Josh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum
title: This Senator Has Got the Math Wrong About a $15 Minimum Wage
description: John Thune says he earned $6 an hour as a teenager in the 1970s. That would be more than $20 today.
content: Senator John Thune, Republican of South Dakota, said Wednesday that he opposed raising the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour, explaining that he earned just $6 an hour as a teenager working over summer vacations as a restaurant cook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Wreckage of T.W.A. Flight 800 to Be Destroyed Years After Explosion
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said it no longer needed to use a reconstruction of the plane brought down in one of the deadliest crashes in U.S. history.
content: Twenty-five years ago, a Boeing 747 flying from New York City to Paris exploded in midair and broke apart just off the coast of Long Island. All 230 people on board the plane, Trans World Airlines Flight 800, were killed, and the wreckage plummeted into the Atlantic Ocean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan and Hailey Fuchs
title: Biden Seeks More Control Over Postal Service With New Appointments
description: The president nominated three people to the beleaguered agency’s board on a day when the postmaster general, Louis DeJoy, a major Republican donor, faced questioning on Capitol Hill.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Wednesday announced three nominees to fill vacant seats on the Postal Service’s board of governors, a move to increase Democratic influence on the future of the beleaguered agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Bill Wright, Who Broke a Color Barrier in Golf, Dies at 84
description: In 1959, decades before Tiger Woods, Wright became the first Black golfer to win a United States Golf Association event.
content: Bill Wright, the first Black competitor to win a United States Golf Association event in an era when African-Americans were not welcome either in segregated country clubs or in the top amateur and professional ranks, died on Feb. 19 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: For Travel, a Sustainable Comeback?
description: From a newly certified Whale Heritage Site to scenic byways for electric cars, five new initiatives suggest the travel industry may be envisioning a more responsible future.
content: With travel stalled for the past 10 months, its sustainable comeback has been a popular topic. Now with Covid-19 vaccines in distribution, and the prospect of travel reviving later this year, some travel operators, local governments and nonprofit organizations are walking the talk, with new eco-oriented programs, trips, transportation initiatives and preserves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Light
title: 50 Years Later, Gamble and Huff’s Philly Sound Stirs the Soul
description: The songwriters and producers Kenny Gamble and Leon Huff’s Black-owned label Philadelphia International Records turned a city’s aesthetic into a movement that reverberated around the world.
content: By the late 1970s, things had gotten so busy at Philadelphia International Records that the label’s co-founders, Kenny Gamble and Leon Huff, had to leave town to write new songs. During one trip to Jamaica, they were settling in at the piano when a power outage hit the island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Battling the Mob, a Black Officer Came Face to Face With Racism
description: “Black officers fought a different battle” on Jan. 6, said Harry Dunn, a Capitol Police officer. Here is what he saw and heard when rioters, including white supremacists, stormed the Capitol.
content: WASHINGTON — The racist slurs hurled at Harry Dunn, a Capitol Police officer, during the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol were cited as evidence this month in the Senate’s impeachment trial of former President Donald J. Trump. Until this week, Officer Dunn had remained anonymous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Revokes Trump’s Pause on Green Cards
description: Since taking office, President Biden has issued several executive orders and directives aimed at lifting restrictions on immigrants put in place over the past four years.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden reopened the country on Wednesday to people seeking green cards, ending a ban on legal immigration that President Donald J. Trump imposed last spring, citing what he said was the need to protect American jobs during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: After 10 Months at Sea, a Giant Carrier Returns to a Changed Nation
description: A mounting pandemic death toll. A contested election. A riot at the Capitol. “The world at home has become completely different and we don’t know what we are coming home to,” one sailor on the Nimitz said.
content: ABOARD U.S.S. NIMITZ, off California — When this aircraft carrier and its city-size crew departed Naval Base Kitsap in Bremerton, Wash., on April 27, George Floyd was still alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nuwer
title: For Shielding Endangered Neighbors, Pandas Make Flimsy Umbrellas
description: A new study challenges a common hypothesis about how protecting charismatic species also conserves animals that are less well known.
content: Like many undergraduate biology students, Fang Wang was taught that pandas are a prime example of an umbrella species — a charismatic, well-known and usually endangered animal whose protection benefits an entire ecosystem and all the wildlife that lives there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: When an Actor Calls With a Poem to Share
description: A Paris playhouse has developed a program of one-on-one “consultations,” delivered by its artists while the theater is closed.
content: PARIS — “I am calling you for a poetic consultation,” said a warm voice on the telephone. “It all starts with a very simple question: How are you?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni, Jim Tankersley and Emily Cochrane
title: Confirmation in Doubt for Neera Tanden, Biden’s Budget Director Pick
description: The struggle to gain support for the longtime Democratic aide whose combative Twitter posts have drawn criticism reflects miscalculations by the White House and its chief of staff, Ron Klain.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s nominee to head the Office of Management and Budget continued to face Senate opposition on Thursday, narrowing her chances of confirmation and sending White House officials on a frantic search for at least one Republican vote to salvage her nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually.
content: In October, New York City Center reimagined its popular Fall for Dance festival in digital form: Dancers made use of the stage of the empty theater, their performances broadcast to audiences at home. In honor of Black History Month, three of those presentations are streaming again — “Lady Swings the Blues” by the brilliant tap artist Dormeshia; Kyle Abraham’s “to be seen,” danced to Ravel’s “Boléro” by Calvin Royal III of American Ballet Theater; and “Morani/Mungu (Black Warrior/Black God)” by Jamar Roberts, a longtime member of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and that company’s resident choreographer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ibram X. Kendi Likes to Read at Bedtime
description: “I don’t remember the last time the pages of a book were not the final thing I saw before departing off for sleep.”
content: “I don’t remember the last time the pages of a book were not the final thing I saw before departing off for sleep,” says the author, professor and editor, with Keisha Blain, of “Four Hundred Souls: A Community History of African America, 1619-2019.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Has McKinsey Lost Its Luster?
description: More tough headlines for the consulting firm.
content: Partners at McKinsey yesterday voted out their leader, Kevin Sneader, as the company deals with blowback over its role in the U.S. opioid crisis. It was the latest tough headline for the consulting firm, which may face growing threats to its status as a trusted adviser to companies and governments — and as a magnet for top talent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Priya Arora
title: California Reaches Another Bleak Milestone
description: Thursday: More than 50,000 people have died from Covid-19 in the state. Also: More on the Newsom recall effort; and remembering Fry’s Electronics.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Andrea Kannapell
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Facebook takes a side in Myanmar.
content: Facebook said it had banned Myanmar’s military from its platforms, leaving little question that the company was openly siding with the country’s pro-democracy movement against the figures who abruptly seized power on Feb. 1, ousting the civilian leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: Are Disposables the Future of Photo Sharing?
description: Some are calling David Dobrik’s new photo app, Dispo, the next Instagram.
content: Dispo, a new photo-sharing app that mimics the experience of using a disposable camera, is taking off. People are clamoring for invites to test the beta version. Early adopters are praising its social features. And investors are betting big on its future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Afghan Government Backs Repatriation of Guantánamo Detainee
description: Afghanistan has intervened in U.S. federal court seeking the return of an Afghan prisoner who has been held since 2007, but never charged.
content: WASHINGTON — The government of Afghanistan has filed a petition in federal court supporting the return of a citizen who has been held for a third of his life at Guantánamo Bay and now argues that, based on a series of peace agreements in his fractious country, his war is over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: After the Riot, What’s the Future of Art in the Capitol?
description: Built largely by enslaved people, the building includes just one small object honoring their work.
content: In the culture wars that spilled over during President Donald Trump’s time in office, the most visible flash point was whether to preserve or destroy monuments depicting figures from America’s racist history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada’s Top Military Officer Steps Aside Amid Investigation
description: The inquiry into Adm. Art McDonald comes amid a second, separate investigation into accusations that his predecessor engaged in sexual impropriety.
content: OTTAWA — Canada’s top military officer temporarily stepped aside as chief of the defense staff after military police opened an investigation into unspecified accusations against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Stenquist
title: The Future of Car Navigation Has Arrived
description: Augmented reality and directions in the windshield: Integrated systems run (precise) laps around earlier technology, like a piano-roll device from the 1930s.
content: The next time your car’s navigation system takes you right to the front door of a perfect little back-road barbecue joint, thank the U.S. military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Alan Yuhas
title: Is ‘Avalanche’ the Answer to a 62-Year-Old Russian Mystery Over 9 Deaths?
description: Was it U.F.O.s? Yeti? The K.G.B.? The riddle of who or what killed nine young hikers has inspired conspiracy theories for decades. Two scientists now say a natural disaster may be to blame.
content: MOSCOW — What drove nine experienced hikers, some barefoot and almost naked, out of their tent and into the subzero cold and the tomblike darkness of the Russian wilderness in 1959?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: With ‘The Father,’ a Playwright Pivots to the Screen
description: Florian Zeller has found success in the theater and as a novelist. Now, his first movie as a director is nominated for four Golden Globe Awards.
content: PARIS — After charming Broadway and the West End, the French playwright and director Florian Zeller may be about to repeat the trick with Hollywood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Gubar
title: Vaccine Hesitancy in Cancer Patients
description: “If I accept the vaccine,” one cancer patient says, “it will be with a strong feeling of guilt that at best I will be prolonging my life for a few months or years.”
content: Do the vaccines against the coronavirus offer cancer patients the same hope that they hold out to healthy people? The women in my cancer support group expressed hesitancy as the vaccines started to be administered to health care workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Chief of Cherokee Nation Asks Jeep to Stop Using Tribe’s Name
description: The carmaker that owns Jeep defended its use of the Native American tribe’s name on its S.U.V. and said it was “committed to a respectful and open dialogue.”
content: The Cherokee Nation, for the first time, has asked Jeep to change the name of its Grand Cherokee vehicle, a move that the carmaker, preparing to release the next generation of the line, has so far resisted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: School Closures Have Failed America’s Children
description: As many as three million children have gotten no education for nearly a year.
content: Flags are flying at half-staff across the United States to commemorate the half-million American lives lost to the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden is preparing to call Saudi Arabia’s monarch before releasing a damning report on Jamal Khashoggi’s death.
description: President Biden plans to hold his first conversation with the ailing Saudi monarch, King Salman this week. And while the call will be full of diplomatic pleasantries, officials say, the real purpose is for Mr. Biden to warn that the United States will soon declassify and publish an intelligence report about the killing of the dissident and journalist Jamal Khashoggi.
content: President Biden plans to hold his first conversation with the ailing Saudi monarch, King Salman this week. title: Police in Malta Say Arrests Are Complete in Journalist’s 2017 Murder
description: The force’s commissioner said everyone believed to be involved in the car bombing that killed Daphne Caruana Galizia was in custody. But a motive remains unclear.
content: More than three years after a car bomb killed Malta’s best-known journalist and sent shock waves across Europe, the head of the Mediterranean island nation’s police force has declared that all those it believes to have been involved in the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia have now been arrested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitra Taj, Anatoly Kurmanaev, Manuela Andreoni and Daniel Politi
title: ‘V.I.P. Immunization’ for the Powerful and Their Cronies Rattles South America
description: A wave of corruption scandals is exposing how the powerful and well-connected in South America jumped the line to get vaccines early. Public dismay is turning into anger.
content: LIMA, Peru — The hope brought by the arrival of the first vaccines in South America is hardening into anger as inoculation campaigns have spiraled into scandal, cronyism and corruption, rocking national governments and sapping trust in the political establishment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Squealing Children and Noisy Neighbors? There’s a Map for That
description: The crowdsourced guide collects anonymous gripes and pins every grievance on an interactive map, creating a record of the irritating sounds and sights of Japan.
content: Noisy children skateboarding on the streets. Couples arguing in their homes. People gathered on the sidewalk, gossiping for long hours. Some people would describe these activities as noise pollution. A new website in Japan has put perpetrators on a map, spurring debate about those who disturb the peace.
source.name: The New York Times

title: California Man Died After Police Knelt on Him for 5 Minutes, Family Says

content: When Maria Quinto-Collins started filming her son at her home in Antioch, Calif., on Dec. 23, he was already on the floor, unresponsive.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Learning to Listen to Patients’ Stories

content: The pandemic has been a time of painful social isolation for many. Few places can be as isolating as hospitals, where patients are surrounded by strangers, subject to invasive tests and attached to an assortment of beeping and gurgling machines.

title: Militia Groups Want to ‘Blow Up the Capitol,’ a Police Chief Testifies
description: The acting chief of the force that protects the Capitol said security measures, including fencing and the presence of the National Guard, should continue amid persisting threats.
content: WASHINGTON — The acting chief of the Capitol Police warned lawmakers on Thursday that extremist groups that carried out the Jan. 6 riot want to blow up the Capitol and kill lawmakers around President Biden’s first formal address to Congress, calling for security measures deployed after the deadly attack to remain for several more weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Florence Birdwell, Singing Teacher to Broadway Stars, Dies at 96
description: She was a tough yet empathetic voice professor at Oklahoma City University for 67 years. Two of her students, Kelli O’Hara and Kristin Chenoweth, won Tony Awards.

source.name: The New York Times

title: My Year of Grief and Cancellation
description: What was I trying to accomplish with my anonymous Tumblr?
content: If you were on Tumblr in the early 2010s, you may remember a blog called Your Fave Is Problematic. If not, its content should still sound familiar to you. title: What to Watch For at CPAC: Trump, Cruz, Pompeo and More
description: Even more than usual, the Conservative Political Action Conference this year will be a barometer for the Republican Party, newly out of power in Washington and trying to chart a way back.
content: Starting on Friday, a medley of conservative politicians, commentators and activists will descend on Orlando, Fla., for the annual Conservative Political Action Conference, commonly known as CPAC. In years past, the event has been a reliable barometer for the base of the Republican Party, clarifying how its most devout members define the institution now, and what they want it to look like in the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Sacha Baron Cohen Has a Message for Mark Zuckerberg
description: The actor who, as Borat, drew our attention to racism, misogyny and autocratic propaganda calls out the social media companies who profit off these trends.
content: Sacha Baron Cohen was busy last year. In “The Trial of The Chicago 7,” he portrayed 1960s antiwar activist Abbie Hoffman. In “Borat Subsequent Moviefilm,” he revived his role as a Kazakh journalist touring America. These films may seem historical or comedic, respectively, but Baron Cohen says their themes — abuse of political power, misogyny and disinformation — are reflective of our current reality. He blames two things: Donald Trump and social media.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Twitter Shakes Off the Cobwebs With New Product Plans
description: Though it has received outsized attention for the last few years, the company has not changed very much. But a recent acquisition spree signals a new course.

content: Lincoln Center is known for the grandeur of its theaters and concert halls: the stately, majestic Metropolitan Opera House, which seats 3,800; David Geffen Hall, aglow as New York Philharmonic fans file in for an evening performance; the David H. Koch Theater, home to New York City Ballet and designed specifically with dance in mind.

title: Manhattan D.A. Now Has Trump’s Tax Returns

title: Can Australia Save Journalism From the Internet?
description: Google and Facebook have objected to a law that will require them to pay media outlets for content. But the legislation won’t protect the businesses it aims to help.
content: Last week Facebook carried out what may have been the single largest content takedown in its history. Any content that looked vaguely like news, even if it very much was not, disappeared from the platform in Australia. The company was demonstrating its opposition to a law now passed by the Australian Parliament that could require technology companies to compensate news organizations for their content.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Susan Feingold Dies at 95; Helped Give New York Children a Head Start
description: Her Bloomingdale Family Program provided preschoolers with a haven where there hadn’t been one before. It became a model for similar efforts under Lyndon Johnson’s War on Poverty.
content: In the 1960s, New York City presented a harsh landscape for its underprivileged children. Parks were dangerous, the courtyards of crumbling housing projects could be hostile zones, and preschools were expensive.
